content: The Act is titled the "Federal Emergency Procurement Flexibility Act of 2001" and includes provisions for contracting related to humanitarian, peacekeeping, and contingency operations. The Federal Emergency Procurement Flexibility Act of 2001 increases the simplified acquisition threshold to $100,000, or five times that amount for contracts related to military operations, humanitarian assistance, foreign disaster assistance, or peacekeeping operations under the United Nations Charter. The Federal Emergency Procurement Flexibility Act of 2001 raises the simplified acquisition threshold to $100,000 or five times that amount for contracts related to military operations, humanitarian assistance, foreign disaster assistance, or peacekeeping operations under the United Nations Charter. Amendments are made to the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 and Title 10 of the United States Code. Title 10, United States Code, is amended by removing unnecessary language and references. During fiscal years 2002 and 2003, the micro-purchase threshold for certain procurements related to defense against terrorism or NBCRT attack is increased to $25,000. Additionally, commercial items authorities are applied to specific procurements. During fiscal years 2002 and 2003, the head of an executive agency can use specific laws to procure property or services for defense against terrorism or NBCRT attack, regardless of whether they are commercial items. The laws include sections of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act, title 10 of the United States Code, and the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949. The Administrative Services Act of 1949 exempts purchases of property or services for defense against terrorism or NBCRT attack from the $5,000,000 limitation on simplified acquisition procedures. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will provide guidance on using these procedures for such purchases. Authority for simplified acquisition procedures for purchases over $5,000,000 will continue to apply under certain provisions of law, despite expiration under the Clinger-Cohen Act of 1996. SEC. 5. USE OF STREAMLINED PROCEDURES. During fiscal years 2002 and 2003, the head of an executive agency is authorized to use streamlined acquisition authorities and procedures for acquiring property or services to enhance defense against terrorism or NBCRT attack. This includes specific provisions under the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949. During fiscal years 2002 and 2003, the head of an executive agency is authorized to use streamlined acquisition authorities and procedures for acquiring property or services to enhance defense against terrorism or NBCRT attack. This includes specific provisions under the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949. Additionally, various sections in Title 41 and Title 10 of the United States Code outline procedures for orders under task and delivery order contracts, as well as the inapplicability of a requirement for procurement notice under the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act. SEC. 317 of the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949 authorizes research and development to enhance defense against terrorism or NBCRT attack. The head of an executive agency is authorized to engage in research and development projects related to defense against terrorism or NBCRT attack. They may exercise the same authority as the Secretary of Defense, except for certain restrictions. The head of an executive agency can engage in research and development projects related to defense against terrorism or NBCRT attacks with authorization from the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. An NBCRT attack is defined as a nuclear, biological, chemical, or radiological attack on the US or a technological attack on a national security system. The annual report required under subsection (h) of section 2371 of title 10, US Code, must be submitted to specific committees. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will create regulations for the Senate and House of Representatives committees. A clerical amendment will be made to the table of sections. "Temporary authority granted for executive agencies to conduct prototype projects under section 317 of the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949, in line with requirements of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1994." The Conforming authority for prototype projects under the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1994 includes the application of specific requirements and conditions, with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget performing certain functions. SEC. 7. IDENTIFICATION OF NEW ENTRANTS INTO THE FEDERAL MARKETPLACE. The head of each executive agency must conduct ongoing market research to identify capabilities, including those of small businesses and new entrants, for meeting agency requirements in defense against terrorism or NBCRT attack. Commercially available market research methods should be utilized to the maximum extent possible. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. The term "NBCRT attack" refers to nuclear, biological, chemical, or radiological attacks against the United States or technological attacks on national security systems. The term "executive agency" is defined as in the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act.
